thread.title: Week four: Redskins vs Eagles preview
thread.title_full: Week four: Redskins vs Eagles preview

title: Week four: Redskins vs Eagles preview
text:
Facebook Email Twitter Google+ LinkedIn Pinterest Week four: Redskins vs Eagles preview We take a look at some of the key match ups ahead of Sunday's divisional showdown at FedEx Field. Post to Facebook Week four: Redskins vs Eagles preview We take a look at some of the key match ups ahead of Sunday's divisional showdown at FedEx Field.  //on.wusa9.com/1Rn0xWc   Join the Conversation To   Week four: Redskins vs Eagles preview Sam C. LaPaille, WUSA9 12:43 p.m. EDT October 3, 2015 Dec 20, 2014; Landover, MD, USA; Washington Redskins tight end Jordan Reed (86) runs with the ball as Philadelphia Eagles cornerback Brandon Boykin (22) attempts the tackle in the third quarter at FedEx Field. The Redskins won 27-24. Mandatory Credit: Geoff Burke-USA TODAY Sports (Photo: Geoff Burke, Geoff Burke-USA TODAY Sports) CONNECT TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
WASHINGTON (WUSA9) -- The Washington Redskins (1-2) are set to take on the Philadelphia Eagles (1-2) on Sunday afternoon at FedEx Field. 
After a disappointing 32-21 loss to the Giants last week, the Redskins will be looking to rebound in front of their home crowd in a key divisional showdown. The NFC East is still wide open and a win for the Burgundy and Gold could keep them in the thick of the race for the division crown. 
We take a look at the key match ups going into Sunday's tilt with the Eagles: 
Kirk Cousins vs. Sam Bradford 
Sunday's forecast is calling for rain thanks to Hurricane Joaquin, meaning the usually sloppy playing surface of FedEx Field will be especially volatile, making the turnover battle extremely important. Cousins and Bradford have each had their ups and downs this season so far. 
Cousins showed signs of stability against the Rams, a game which he managed beautifully, making good decisions and not costing his team the win with bad interceptions. But the old Cousins resurfaced against the Giants last week. Cousins was picked off twice, both being throws that he tried to force into tight windows. 
Sam Bradford has been just as shaky as Cousins, showing brilliance at sometimes (see second half against Atlanta in week one), but then disappearing for long stretches of time (see entire game against Dallas in week 2). So far, the Eagles' offense is a far cry from the high-flying juggernaut it was supposed to be and Bradford shoulders not all, but part of the blame. 
Sunday's game could be decided by one errant throw or one wise check down instead of heaving a prayer into double coverage. The question is: Who will make more good decisions? Cousins or Bradford? 
Redskins Special Teams vs. Darren Sproles 
The Redskins' special teams unit has been woeful this year, allowing a punt return touchdown in week one and having a punt blocked for a safety last week against the Giants. Sure, Rashad Ross had a beautiful 101-yard kickoff return touchdown against the Giants, but by then, the game was out of hand. 
Jay Gruden continues to bring up the losses of key special teamers Niles Paul and Adam Hayward, citing their absence as one of the main reasons special teams have been so dreadful. But this is a "next man up" league and it's time for players to start making plays. 
Things don't get easier when Philly rolls into town with Darren Sproles, one of the leagues best return men. Sproles had an electrifying punt return touchdown last week against the New York Jets, a play that jump started the Eagles' victory. 
Special teams have let the Redskins down this season. Another lackluster performance from the unit could send the Redskins to the NFC East cellar. Containing Sproles will be key, but every player on Washington's special teams needs to make sure they have the New England Patriots' mantra in mind: "Do your job." 
Like this story? Like WUSA9 on Facebook .
